wikipedia_page.main: William Lane (1746–1814) was a publisher and bookseller in London in the late 18th century. Around 1790 he established the Minerva Printing Press in Cree Church Lane, Leadenhall Street, moving ca.1792 to no. 31 Leadenhall Street. The Minerva Press issued works by Courtney Melmoth and others. Subscribers to Lane's Circulating Library (established circa 1774) included Leigh Hunt. Around 1799 John Darling and Anthony King Newman joined Lane as "Lane, Darling, Newman & Co." In 1804 Lane retired and Newman took over the business.

response: *unknown date – William Lane establishes the Minerva Press in London, specializing in Gothic fiction.

Minerva Press was a publishing house, noted for creating a lucrative market in sentimental and Gothic fiction in the late 18th century and early 19th century. It was established by William Lane (c. 1745–1814) at No 33 Leadenhall Street, London, when he moved his circulating library there in about 1790.

The Star was a London evening newspaper founded on 3 May 1788, originally under the title Star and Evening Advertiser, and was the first daily evening newspaper in the world.British Library: Concise History of the British Newspaper in the Eighteenth Century. Founding sponsors of the new paper included publisher John Murray and William Lane of the Minerva Press.
William Lane (1861–1917) was a journalist and pioneer of the Australian labour movement.
William Lane may also refer to:
*William Lane (died c. 1438), Member of Parliament (MP) for Canterbury
*William Lane (died 1618) (1553–1618), MP for Northamptonshire and Gatton
*William Lane (cricketer) (1845–1939), English banker, magistrate and cricketer
*William Lane (priest), a Canon of Windsor from 1403 to 1404
*William Lane Craig (born 1949), American analytic philosopher, philosophical theologian, and Christian apologist
*William Lane (horn player), American French horn player and long-time Principal Horn of the Los Angeles Philharmonic

In London he obtained an engagement with William Lane, the proprietor of the Minerva Library, at 53 Leadenhall Street. He subsequently worked for John and Arthur Arch, the Quaker booksellers of Gracechurch Street, where he stayed until he began business on his own account.
